para.paratext: The extent to which a party is bound by his own testimony is “one of the most troublesome questions in the law of evidence and has been the subject of much diversity of judicial opinion.”[1] Interestingly, a party may introduce evidence to contradict his own testimony.

The problematic statement that a party is “not entitled to a finding in his favor if that version of his testimony the most unfavorable to him shows that the verdict should be against him”[2] recurs in a number of Georgia cases. This statement comes from an early case[3] which included the clause “in the absence of information from other sources.” Failure to add this clause in subsequent judicial decisions has caused confusion about whether a party can introduce evidence to contradict his own testimony.[4]

As the Georgia Court of Appeals held in Marett v. Professional Ins. Careers, Inc.,[5] “the law in this state is that the testimony of a party offering himself as a witness in his own behalf is to be construed most strongly against him when it is contradictory, vague, or equivocal.” In that case, the plaintiff sought to pierce the corporate veil and hold an individual defendant responsible for certain contractual fees. However, the plaintiff testified that the defendant entered the contract individually, that the defendant entered the contract on behalf of the corporate defendant, and that the plaintiff did not know who entered the contract. The appellate court reversed the trial court's failure to direct a verdict for the individual defendant.

However, in Bramblett v. Hansel-Scales, Inc.,[6] the appellate court reversed a summary judgment for the defendant in a slip-and-fall case because the trial court mistakenly determined that the plaintiff's testimony was contradictory and eliminated from consideration the most favorable part of the plaintiff's testimony. In that case, the plaintiff testified by deposition that she had no personal knowledge of what caused her to fall but contended that the cause was an uneven condition resulting from the carpeting covering a raised board at the head of a stairway. The appellate court found that there was no contradiction because the plaintiff had not been looking down at the time of her fall and could show through other evidence that the condition of the carpeting caused the fall.

Likewise, in Partridge v. Partridge,[7] the Supreme Court held that, although the wife provided conflicting testimony when she testified that she did not want any of her husband's estate or property, but on direct examination stated she needed financial help from her husband to maintain her lifestyle and be able to support the children, it was for the trial court to resolve the conflicting testimony, and the award of alimony was upheld.

The self-contradictory testimony rule does not apply to testimony of non-parties.[8] Moreover, where the party's “statement” is non-verbal, such as maintained silence, the statement needs to be intended as a assertion to be admissible.[9]

Davis v. Akridge, 199 Ga. 867, 36 S.E.2d 102 (1945); Partain v. King, 206 Ga. 530, 57 S.E.2d 617 (1950); Dollar v. Dollar, 214 Ga. 499, 105 S.E.2d 736 (1958); Ray v. Marett, 84 Ga. App. 86, 65 S.E.2d 646 (1951); Thompson v. Gore, 98 Ga. App. 231, 105 S.E.2d 359 (1958); Bedingfield v. McCullough, 106 Ga. App. 759, 128 S.E.2d 374 (1962).
Western & A.R. Co. v. Evans, 96 Ga. 481, 23 S.E. 494 (1895).
Taylor v. Wilson, 109 Ga. App. 658, 137 S.E.2d 353 (1964); Wilson v. Matthews, 122 Ga. App. 67, 176 S.E.2d 178 (1970).
Marett v. Professional Ins. Careers, Inc., 201 Ga. App. 178, 410 S.E.2d 373 (1991).

See also Williams v. Food Lion, Inc., 213 Ga. App. 865, 446 S.E.2d 221 (1994), wherein the Court of Appeals held that, under the rule that party's own testimony is to be construed most strongly against him when it is self-contradictory, vague or equivocal, contradictions within a store patron's testimony should be resolved against him on the store owner's motion for summary judgment.
Bramblett v. Hansel-Scales, Inc., 200 Ga. App. 722, 409 S.E.2d 280 (1991).

James v. Georgia Department of Public Safety, 337 Ga. App. 864, 789, 789 S.E.2d 236 (2016) (self-contradictory testimony rule did not apply to disregard testimony of pursuing State Patrol officers, who were two witnesses for the Department of Public Safety in wrongful death action alleging that an officer negligently failed to comply with Department's pursuit policy by continuing a vehicle chase and executing a Precision Immobilization Technique (PIT) maneuver; neither witness was a party to the litigation, and the Tort Claims Act prohibited witnesses from being parties to the litigation).
